title: Deffer Wood Cawthorne Walk Route

images.title: Matthew Hatton / Bluebells in Deffer Wood, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Bluebells in Deffer Wood

images.title: Nigel Homer / Deffer Wood, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Deffer Wood in late autumn. Deffer wood is planted with Corsican Pine and Giant Fir, but this area on the edge contains a mixture of oak, sycamore and birch

images.title: John Fielding / Fields and Deffer Wood, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Fields and Deffer Wood From New Road between High Hoyland and Cawthorne

images.title: Nigel Homer / Path to Deffer Wood, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Path to Deffer Wood.  Deffer Wood - one of the largest expanses of (working) coniferous plantation in the area. In bulk, mature woodland, it has several areas which have been clear-felled and replanted producing areas of uneven age woodland.

images.title: Matthew Hatton / Odd little Summer House in Deffer Wood, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Odd little Summer House in the wood. Unfortunately the graffiti merchants have drawn a huge head on the inside of this building and carved their names into the wooden joists.

images.title: Nigel Homer / Intersection of footpaths, Deffer Wood, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Intersection of footpaths, Deffer Wood. The woods are a good spot to see a wide range of woodland species including all three woodpeckers, Pied Flycatcher, and in the more mature sections of coniferous plantation Crossbills.

description:
This circular walk visits Deffer Wood in West Yorkshire. The woods are a peaceful place with nice trails and lots of bluebells in the spring months.
You can start the walk from the car park at Cannon Hall Country Park and follow a footpath north west along the Jowett House Beck to the woods. The walk then explores the woods on various paths before picking up another public footpath at the eastern end. This will take you along the edge of the park toward the village of Cawthorne. From here you can follow the waymarked Barnsley Boundary Walk back to the car park where the route finishes. In the woods look out for a variety of woodland birds including woodpeckers, pied flycatcher and crossbill. At the northern end of the woods you can pick up our Denby Dale Circular Walk which explores the area surrounding the village.
